passages.text: Consumer | Retail Broadlines & Hardlines
Petco Health and Wellness Company Inc WOOF| \(\) 3.25\$ In Line | Target Price/Base Case: \(\) 400\$ Earnings Report
Company Statistics52-Week Range$2.28 - $6.29Base Case$4.00Upside/Downside23.8%Market Capitalization (M)$883Price/Earnings21.8Forward P/E16.6EV / EBITDA5.82Short Interest13.5%
1 Year Price History

Petco's focus on retail fundamentals is paying dividends in the form of gross margin expansion, SG&A leverage, and profitability improvements. The top line remains the concern. With comps down \(1.6\%\) (Street was expecting \(- 1.3\%\) ) Petco is losing share as mgmt. sacrifices near- term sales in an effort to recalibrate the earnings base. Outside the top line sluggishness, 2Q results featured 120bps of gross margin expansion coupled with SG&A expenses down \(6\%\) y/y, resulting in \(\) 114\(mn of adj. EBITDA and WOOF's best 2Q margin (7.6\%) since 2022. The progress has been made through basic retail blocking & tackling: closing unprofitable stores, merchandise review down to the SKU level, and stripping out unnecessary costs. Shrinking into success comes at a cost however, as WOOF continues to cede share with the broader pet industry now stabilized, and recent PCE data suggesting a reacceleration to growth. Despite the improved margin backdrop, mgmt. reiterated the full year guide of sales down LSD. With 2Q EBITDA coming in -\) 525mn ahead of expectations and general 1H profitability tracking ahead, mgmt. appears ready to flirt with the move into phase 3 (the return to growth) with investments planned into 2H. This could help explain why mgmt. upped their FY EBITDA guide by just \(\) 8\$ mn despite the \(\) 25\$ mn beat in 2Q. While the turnaround in profitability has been impressive, execution into phase 3 will prove pivotal and until we get more confidence in WOOF's ability to stop the bleeding on share (competition not getting easier), we remain on the sidelines. 6.5x 2026e EBITDA (incl. stock- based comp) gets us to \(\) 4\$ in our base case. For a bull- bear discussion, see inside.

What we liked: Gross Margin. Cost- Out. Profitability. Return to Growth on Deck. 2Q gross margin improved 120bps y/y, well ahead of expectations for 25- 30bps of expansion. Petco has emphasized the opportunity within GM as an integral part in improving profitability however the speed and magnitude has impressed. Targeting both unit costs and retail prices while ditching the "empty calorie" promotions (particularly online) has led the improvement. Credit mgmt for continuing to find ways to strip costs out of SG&A without damaging the customer experience. 2Q's \(6\%\) decline in SG&A follows 1Q's \(- 7\%\) and speaks to the focus around establishing a baseline of profitability before returning to growth. EBITDA margins above \(7\%\) were last seen in 2022. With profitability in better shape mgmt. spoke to beginner investments in 2H that suggest phase 3 (the return to growth) could be coming shortly.

What to watch: Share Slip. Tariffs. Shrinking Again. With 3Q and FY sales guided down LSD, WOOF's profit improvement is coming at the cost of continued share losses. CHWY, TSCO, AMZN, mass merchants, and more are serving as tough competition and the longer Petco remains heads down on internal improvement, the bigger the hole will be to regain customers. Gross margins have been a welcome development, especially in 2Q but mgmt. calling out tariffs headwinds that arise in 3Q and get worse again in 4Q suggest 2H gross margins will have a tougher road ahead.

Bottom Line: Petco's stock has regressed sharply from peak levels in 2022. While they have battled challenges associated with mix, we think mgmt's move to reset the core profitability of the company is a prudent step in restoring value. Longer term, we like WOOF's positioning in the attractive pet industry however we think the stock will remain volatile as a new normal is built and growth is restored.

Bull Case - $6Base Case - $4Bear Case - $28x 2026e EV/EBITDA of $470mn6.5x 2026e EV/EBITDA of $412mn5x 2026e EV/EBITDA of $350mnDiscretionary recovery combined with new mgmt. mojo. Expectations for further moderation in 2026 prove too pessimistic as comps snap back to +MSD. Mix starts to improve and margins benefit. More importantly cost out opportunities prove meaningfully greater than originally targeted. Vet clinics expand and drive incremental traffic and sales. Decent FCF generation enables debt buy-down. 8x+ EBITDA is warranted given stability and new mgmt's ability to address concerns.Bark or Bite? It's hard to put too much of a multiple on WOOF currently given share losses, volatility in margins, and FCF. Establishing a more concrete baseline for core operations would be a massive positive for shares, but it will take more than a quarter or two to cause a substantive re-rating. Provided that comps and gross margins don't take another leg down, and FCF generation is positive, a 7x EV/EBITDA multiple (incl. stock-based comp) feels appropriate.Food Scraps. Vet clinic rollout and debt buydown are halted as FCF turns into a cash burn. Consumables are hit, as consumers look to bulk purchasing/trade down to combat spending pressure. Petco struggles to keep 4-wall EBITDA targets as the discretionary outlook remains constrained. GMs remain mix dependent. Hypercompetitive pet market squeezes margins further. Stock falls to 5x 2026 EBITDA.
Source: Company Data, FactSet, Evercore ISI Research

How Successful Will Services Rollout Be? In addition to Petco's higher- end consumables offering- which differentiates the company from mass merchants and grocery stores, the buildout of in- store vet clinics, grooming and training are additional big differentiators for Petco that can help to increase ticket and traffic to their stores. 4- Wall economics are encouraging, but the sample size is still small. Getting to a critical mass in vet clinics will be important to judge if the revenue and EBITDA lift per store are translating across the fleet.

How Quickly Can Petco Build Out Its Multichannel Offering? With the company behind key multichannel Hardlines Retailers in its multichannel offering, the question arises how quickly they can a) increase online sales & eComm penetration and b) make continued investments to support curbside, contactless pickup, and ship from store (same day, next day) at their entire store fleet. With vets and other services providing foot traffic into their stores, the company's best chance to grow above trend rests within the development of its multichannel offering to benefit from store traffic and online growth.

When will discretionary recover? Historical comparisons are a helpful tool (i.e. PetSmart); however, WOOF's competitors never cycled pandemic boosted discretionary spending capacity. Petco's margins and mix have already shifted in excess of comparisons and likely will not improve absolutely until 2025.

1. Increased spend from customers using more than one channel  
2. Vet rollout  
3. Multichannel/eComm penetration and improving digital margins

1. Manufacturers of Premium foods open distribution to Discounters/ Clubs/ Mass Merchants  
2. Online sales of pet products accelerate as AMZN/CHWY open more automated FCs closer to its customers  
3. Variable & elevated debt structure  
4. Discretionary demand and mix pressure continue  
5. Moderation of FCF & capital for sq. footage expansion

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:

Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances. Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
